subject: history
title: Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms & Government of India Act 1919
description: Post-WWI constitutional reforms introducing dyarchy system

context: India's massive contribution to WWI (1.3 million soldiers, ¬£100+ million)
Indian expectations of self-government as reward
Russian Revolution (1917) worried British about unrest

montaguDeclaration.by: Edwin Montagu (Secretary of State for India)
montaguDeclaration.promise: Progressive realization of responsible government in India as integral part of British Empire
montaguDeclaration.vague: No timeline; 'gradual' and 'progressive' were escape clauses

details.indianExpectations: Dominion status or substantial self-government; Britain offered much less

legislature.bicameral: Introduced bicameral legislature (two houses) for first time

franchise.limited: Only 1% of population could vote (about 10% males)
franchise.qualifications: High property, income, or educational qualifications
franchise.communalElectorates: Separate electorates continued (for Muslims, Sikhs, etc.)

legislative: Could make laws on subjects except reserved ones
Could discuss budget (but vote only on 25-30%)
limitations: Viceroy had veto power over all legislation
Could certify bills rejected by legislature
Defence, foreign affairs, tribal areas exempted
Governor-General's executive not responsible to legislature

executive.accountability: Executive NOT responsible to legislature (no responsible government)
executive.viceroy: Viceroy remained supreme; could overrule council

stages.label: Provincial Level - DYARCHY System
stages.description: Most significant feature - dual government in provinces

dyarchyMeaning.definition: Dyarchy = Dual Government (Greek: di = two,archy = rule)
dyarchyMeaning.concept: Provincial subjects divided into two categories: Reserved and Transferred
dyarchyMeaning.rationale: Gradual training of Indians in self-government
dyarchyMeaning.reality: Mechanism to maintain British control while appearing to grant power

reservedSubjects.control: Under Governor and Executive Council (British officials)
reservedSubjects.importance: All important subjects kept under British control
reservedSubjects.officials: Executive Council: 2 members (both British or Indian loyalists)

transferredSubjects.importance: Less important subjects; no real financial power
transferredSubjects.ministers: Indian Ministers: 2-3 responsible to Legislative Council

control: Could overrule both reserved and transferred departments
Controlled finance; ministers dependent on him for funds
Special powers for law and order

powers: Could reject bills (but Governor could certify)

indianCouncil.change: Secretary of State's Council (in London) reduced
indianCouncil.salary: Secretary of State now paid from British funds (earlier Indian funds)
indianCouncil.significance: Reduced drain but Secretary of State still powerful

publicServiceCommission.established: High Commissioner for India appointed (in London)
publicServiceCommission.PSC: Public Service Commission to be established (for ICS recruitment)
publicServiceCommission.reality: Very slow; British continued to dominate

communalRepresentation.new: Separate electorates for Sikhs, Anglo-Indians, Europeans, Indian Christians
communalRepresentation.weightage: Muslims given weightage (seats more than population proportion)

franchise.limited: Only 10% males could vote (1% of total population including women)
franchise.basis: Property, income, tax payment, or education
franchise.universal: No universal adult suffrage; vast majority excluded

reviewClause.provision: Statutory Commission to review reforms after 10 years
reviewClause.outcome: Led to Simon Commission (1927) which came 2 years early

positives.detail: Introduced principle of ministerial responsibility (in transferred subjects)
positives.significance: Indians became ministers answerable to elected legislature

positives.detail: 5 million Indians got voting rights (from 1 million earlier)
positives.limitation: Still only 10% of adult males; but expansion nonetheless

positives.detail: Elected Indian members formed majority in provincial councils
positives.significance: Indians could outvote officials and nominated members
More balanced legislation; checks and balances

positives.detail: Indians became ministers in provinces; 3 in Viceroy's Council
Provincial councils could vote on provincial budget (minus reserved)
positives.importance: Some financial power to elected representatives

positives.saving: Secretary of State's salary from British funds (small saving)

reasons: Division into reserved and transferred subjects arbitrary and artificial
All important subjects reserved; ministers got powerless departments
Ministers had no funds; finance under reserved
Governor could interfere in transferred subjects anytime
Confusion and conflict between two wings
Ministers blamed for failures but had no real power
fundamentalFlaws.reality: Set up to fail; Indians made scapegoats for failures

fundamentalFlaws.detail: Neither Viceroy nor Governors responsible to legislatures
fundamentalFlaws.impact: Executive could ignore legislature; no real accountability
fundamentalFlaws.comparison: Britain had responsible government; India denied same

powers: Special powers for 'emergencies' and 'law and order'

problem: Sikhs, Christians, Anglo-Indians also got separate electorates
fundamentalFlaws.congress: Congress opposed as vivisection of nation

fundamentalFlaws.numbers: Only 10% males (1% total population) could vote

fundamentalFlaws.central: Defence, foreign affairs completely excluded from legislature
fundamentalFlaws.provincial: All important subjects reserved under British control

otherCriticisms.anniBesant: Called it 'Unworthy of England to offer, India to accept'
otherCriticisms.moderates: Even moderates disappointed; some accepted reluctantly

stages.label: Indian Reactions & Responses
stages.description: How Indians responded to the reforms

congressSpecialSession.vote: Moderates wanted to accept with reservations; rejected after debate

congressRegularSession.resolution: Reiterated rejection but said will work reforms to expose their inadequacy

muslimLeague.response: Lukewarm; wanted more safeguards for Muslims
muslimLeague.concern: Worried about Hindu majority in legislatures

moderates.response: Disappointed but willing to work within system
moderates.reality: Many gave up politics after dyarchy experience

extremists.anger: After WWI sacrifice, reforms seen as insult

impact: Rowlatt Act was draconian repression (detention without trial)
Rowlatt Act + Jallianwala Bagh Massacre (April 1919) destroyed faith
details.gandhiResponse: Gandhi launched first all-India Satyagraha against Rowlatt Act (April 1919)

assessment.title: Historical Assessment
failure: Did not satisfy any section of Indian opinion
significance: First major constitutional reforms after WWI
Training ground for Indian politicians (despite flaws)
Exposed inadequacy of British willingness to share power
Failure led to demand for complete independence
Proved moderates' faith in British goodwill misplaced
legacy: Indians participated reluctantly to expose flaws
Congress decided to completely reject and launch Non-Cooperation (1920)
Simon Commission (1927) came to review; led to 1935 Act
Dyarchy failure meant 1935 Act had to go further

mustRemember: Government of India Act 1919 = Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms
Key feature: DYARCHY in provinces (Reserved vs Transferred subjects)
Bicameral legislature introduced (Council of State + Legislative Assembly)
Limited franchise: only 10% males could vote
No responsible government - executives not accountable
Dyarchy failed; Congress rejected as inadequate
Rowlatt Act (1919) alongside reforms poisoned atmosphere
examQuestions: Explain dyarchy system and why it failed
Why did Congress reject GOI Act 1919?
